papers.title: Partitioning the vertex set of a bipartite graph into complete bipartite subgraphs
papers.abstract:
<jats:p>Graph Theory</jats:p>
          <jats:p xml:lang="en">Given a graph and a positive integer k, the biclique vertex-partition problem asks whether the vertex set of the graph can be partitioned into at most k bicliques (connected complete bipartite subgraphs). It is known that this problem is ...

        <jats:p>Label propagation is a popular graph-based semi-supervised learning framework. Its effectiveness depends on the distribution of prior labels. If there are no objects with prior labels in parts of classes, the label propagation has a very bad performa...

papers.title: Exact Weight Perfect Matching of Bipartite Graph Problem Simplified
papers.abstract: The study of perebor dates back to the Soviet-era mathematics, especially in the 1980s [1]. Post-Soviet mathematicians has been working on many problems in combinatorial optimization. One of them is Exact Weight Perfect Matching of Bipartite Graph (EWPM). This particular problem has been thorough...

papers.title: The Connectivity of a Bipartite Graph and Its Bipartite Complementary Graph
papers.abstract: <jats:p> In 1956, Nordhaus and Gaddum gave lower and upper bounds on the sum and the product of the chromatic number of a graph and its complement, in terms of the order of the graph. Since then, any bound on the sum and/or the product of an invariant in a graph [Formula: see text] and the same inva...

papers.title: Excluding a bipartite circle graph from line graphs
papers.abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We prove that, for a fixed bipartite circle graph <jats:italic>H</jats:italic>, all line graphs with sufficiently large rank‐width (or clique‐width) must have a pivot‐minor isomorphic to <jats:italic>H</jats:italic>. To prove this, we introduce graphic delta‐...

papers.title: b-CHROMATIC NUMBER OF CORONA PRODUCT OF CROWN GRAPH AND COMPLETE BIPARTITE GRAPH WITH PATH GRAPH
papers.abstract: <jats:p>A b-coloring of a graph is a proper coloring where each color admits at least one node (called dominating node) adjacent to every other used color. The maximum number of colors needed to b-color a graph G is called the b-chromatic number and is denoted by φ(G). In this paper, we find the b-c...
